kdl.prox.util.stat
Class StatUtil

java.lang.Object
  kdl.prox.util.stat.StatUtil

public final class StatUtil
extends java.lang.Object

StatUtil contains various useful static statistical utility methods for modeling.

cramerV

public static double cramerV(double gStat,
                             double n,
                             double r)
Computes Cramer's V statistic for non-square tables. This is similar to phi for square tables. r is defined as the min(|columns|, |rows|).

Parameters:
gStat -
n -
r -
Returns:

equalDoubles

public static boolean equalDoubles(double value,
                                   double otherValue)
Method to compare two doubles for equality. Note: value == otherValue can sometimes evaluate to false even when the numbers are equal because of the limited precision of floating point arithmetic.

inverseStandardNormalCDF

public static double inverseStandardNormalCDF(double P)
DOUBLE PRECISION FUNCTION PPND16 (P, IFAULT)

http://lib.stat.cmu.edu/apstat/241

ALGORITHM AS241 APPL. STATIST. (1988) VOL. 37, NO. 3

Produces the normal deviate Z corresponding to a given lower tail area of P; Z is accurate to about 1 part in 10**16.

The hash sums below are the sums of the mantissas of the coefficients. They are included for use in checking transcription.

Parameters:
P - = cdf value to invert.

inverseChiSquareCDF

public static double inverseChiSquareCDF(double alpha,
                                         long dof,
                                         double epsilon)
                                  throws java.lang.Exception
From http://people.scs.fsu.edu/~burkardt/m_src/prob/chi_square_cdf_inv.m

//// CHI_SQUARE_CDF_INV inverts the Chi squared PDF. // // Modified: // // 11 October 2004 // // Reference: // // Best and Roberts, // The Percentage Points of the Chi-Squared Distribution, // Algorithm AS 91, // Applied Statistics, // Volume 24, Number ?, pages 385-390, 1975. // // Parameters: // // Input, real CDF, a value of the chi-squared cumulative // probability density function. // 0.000002 <= CDF <= 0.999998. // // Input, real A, the parameter of the chi-squared // probability density function. 0 < A. // // Output, real X, the value of the chi-squared random deviate // with the property that the probability that a chi-squared random // deviate with parameter A is less than or equal to PPCHI2 is P. // //

Parameters:
alpha -
dof -
epsilon -
Returns:
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

gStatistic

public static double gStatistic(int[][][] counts)
G^2 statistic is defined as: G^2 = 2 * \sum_{ijk} N_{ijk} ln [(N_{ijk} * N_{k})/(N_{ik} * N_{jk})] where N_{ijk} is the value stored at counts[i][j][k] and something like N_{k} is equal to \sum_{ij} N_{ijk}.

See Spirtes, Glymour, Scheines, 2000

Parameters:
counts -
Returns:
g-statistic

power

public static double power(double alpha,
                           double sampleSize,
                           double effectSize,
                           long dof)
                    throws java.lang.Exception
Utilizes the power approximation supplied in: G.ÊW. Milligan. A computer program for calculating power of the chi-square test. Educational and Psychological Measurement, 39(3):681Ð684, 1979.

lambda = effectSize^2 * sampleSize (from Cohen Chapter 12).

Parameters:
alpha -
sampleSize -
effectSize -
dof -
Returns:
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

phiSquareWithDOFCorrection

public static double phiSquareWithDOFCorrection(double gStat,
                                                double n,
                                                double dof)
Method to compute the effect size of a gStat given the dof and n. Use method from Bishop, Fienberg and Holland: ES = gStat - (dof -1) / n

Parameters:
gStat -
dof -
n -
Returns:
